introduction.p: The last section introduced eigenvalues and eigenvectors, presented the underlying geometric intuition behind their definition, and demonstrated their use in understanding the long-term behavior of certain systems. We will now develop a more algebraic understanding of eigenvalues and eigenvectors. In particular, we will find an algebraic method for determining the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a square matrix.
Let's begin by reviewing some important ideas that we have seen previously.

statement.p: Suppose that A is a square matrix and that the nonzero vector \xvec is a solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec. What can we conclude about the invertibility of A?

solution.p: The matrix cannot have a pivot position in every column so it is not invertible.

statement.p: How does the determinant \det(A) tell us if there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec?

solution.p: If there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec, then A is not invertible so \det(A) = 0.

statement.p:
Suppose that
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] . Find the determinant \det(A). What does this tell us about the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec?

solution.p: We find that \det(A) = 0 so there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation.

statement.p: Find a basis for \nul(A).

solution.p:
The reduced row echelon form of A is
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
so the solution space to the homogeneous equation may be described parametrically as x=x_3\threevec{-1}{-2}{1}. A basis for \nul(A) is therefore \threevec{-1}{-2}{1}.

statement.p: What is the relationship between the rank of a matrix and the dimension of its null space?

solution.p: If A is an n\times n matrix, then \dim~\nul(A) = n-\rank(A).

subsection.title: The characteristic polynomial

statement.p:
The eigenvalues of a square matrix are defined by the condition that there be a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation (A-\lambda I)\vvec=\zerovec.
If there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation (A-\lambda I)\vvec = \zerovec, what can we conclude about the invertibility of the matrix A-\lambda I?
If there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation (A-\lambda I)\vvec = \zerovec, what can we conclude about the determinant \det(A-\lambda I)?
Let's consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
from which we construct
A-\lambda I = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] - \lambda \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1-\lambda \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1-\lambda \\ \end{array}\right] . Find the determinant \det(A-\lambda I). What kind of equation do you obtain when we set this determinant to zero to obtain \det(A-\lambda I) = 0?
Use the determinant you found in the previous part to find the eigenvalues \lambda by solving the equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0. We considered this matrix in so we should find the same eigenvalues for A that we found by reasoning geometrically there.
Consider the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] and find its eigenvalues by solving the equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0.
Consider the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] and find its eigenvalues by solving the equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0.
Find the eigenvalues of the triangular matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . What is generally true about the eigenvalues of a triangular matrix?

li.p: The matrix A-\lambda I cannot be invertible.
It must be the case that \det(A-\lambda I) = 0.
We find that \det(A-\lambda I) = \lambda^2 - 2\lambda - 3 = 0.
\lambda^2 - 2\lambda - 3= (\lambda-3)(\lambda+1) = 0 so we find eigenvalues \lambda = 3 and \lambda = -1.
For this matrix, we have \det(A-\lambda I) = (\lambda-2)^2=0 so there is one eigenvalue, \lambda = 2.
\det(A-\lambda I) = \lambda^2 + 1 = 0 so there are complex eigenvalues, \lambda = i and \lambda = -i.
Because the determinant of a triangular matrix equals the product of its diagonal entries, The eigenvalues are equal to the entries on the diagonal.

subsection.p:
This activity demonstrates a technique that enables us to find the eigenvalues of a square matrix A. Since an eigenvalue \lambda is a scalar for which the equation (A-\lambda I)\vvec = \zerovec has a nonzero solution, it must be the case that A-\lambda I is not invertible. Therefore, its determinant is zero. This gives us the equation
\det(A-\lambda I) = 0
whose solutions are the eigenvalues of A. This equation is called the characteristic equation of A. characteristic equation

characteristic polynomial In general, the expression \det(A-\lambda I) is a polynomial in \lambda, which is called the characteristic polynomial of A. If A is an n\times n matrix, the degree of the characteristic polynomial is n. For instance, if A is a 2\times2 matrix, then \det(A-\lambda I) is a quadratic polynomial; if A is a 3\times3 matrix, then \det(A-\lambda I) is a cubic polynomial.
The matrix in has a characteristic polynomial with two real and distinct roots. This will not always be the case, as demonstrated in the next two examples.

example.p:
Consider the matrix A=\begin{bmatrix} 5 \amp -1\\ 4 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} , whose characteristic equation is
\lambda^2 - 6\lambda + 9 = (\lambda-3)^2 = 0.
In this case, the characteristic polynomial has one real root, which means that this matrix has a single real eigenvalue, \lambda = 3.

subsection.title: Finding eigenvectors
subsection.p: Now that we can find the eigenvalues of a square matrix A by solving the characteristic equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0, we will turn to the question of finding the eigenvectors associated to an eigenvalue \lambda. The key, as before, is to note that an eigenvector is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation (A-\lambda I)\vvec = \zerovec. In other words, the eigenvectors associated to an eigenvalue \lambda form the null space \nul(A-\lambda I).

This shows that the eigenvectors associated to an eigenvalue form a subspace of \real^n. We will denote the subspace of eigenvectors of a matrix A associated to the eigenvalue \lambda by E_\lambda and note that
E_\lambda = \nul(A-\lambda I) . We say that E_\lambda is the eigenspace of A associated to the eigenvalue \lambda. eigenspace

statement.p:
In this activity, we will find the eigenvectors of a matrix as the null space of the matrix A-\lambda I.
Let's begin with the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . We have seen that \lambda = 3 is an eigenvalue. Form the matrix A-3I and find a basis for the eigenspace E_3 = \nul(A-3I). What is the dimension of this eigenspace? For each of the basis vectors \vvec, verify that A\vvec = 3\vvec.
We also saw that \lambda = -1 is an eigenvalue. Form the matrix A-(-1)I and find a basis for the eigenspace E_{-1}. What is the dimension of this eigenspace? For each of the basis vectors \vvec, verify that A\vvec = -\vvec.
Is it possible to form a basis of \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A?
Now consider the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] . Write the characteristic equation for A and use it to find the eigenvalues of A. For each eigenvalue, find a basis for its eigenspace E_\lambda. Is it possible to form a basis of \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A?
Next, consider the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] . Write the characteristic equation for A and use it to find the eigenvalues of A. For each eigenvalue, find a basis for its eigenspace E_\lambda. Is it possible to form a basis of \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A?
Finally, find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the diagonal matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Explain your result by considering the geometric effect of the matrix transformation defined by A.

li.p: We can form a basis for \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A by taking \left\{\twovec{1}{1}, \twovec{-1}{1}\right\}.

The characteristic equation is (3-\lambda)^2 = 0, which means that there is a single eigenvalue \lambda=3. This eigenspace is two-dimensional with basis \left\{\twovec{1}{0},\twovec{0}{1}\right\}. In this case, we can form a basis for \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors of A.

The characteristic equation is (2-\lambda)^2 = 0 so there is again a single eigenvalue \lambda=2. In this case, the eigenspace is one-dimensional with basis vector \twovec{1}{0}. It is not possible to form a basis for \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors.
We have eigenvectors \twovec10 with associated eigenvector \lambda=4 and \twovec01 with associated eigenvector \lambda=-1.

subsection.p: Once we find an eigenvalue of a matrix A, describing the associated eigenspace E_\lambda amounts to the familiar task of describing the null space \nul(A-\lambda I).

example.p: Revisiting the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -4 \amp 4 \\ -12 \amp 10 \\ \end{array}\right] from , we recall that we found eigenvalues \lambda = 4 and \lambda = 2.

Considering the eigenvalue \lambda = 4, we have
A -4I = \begin{bmatrix} -8 \amp 4 \\ -12 \amp 6 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -1/2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Since the eigenvectors \vvec = \twovec{v_1}{v_2} are the solutions of the equation (A-4I)\vvec=\zerovec, we see that they are determined by the single equation v_1-\frac12 v_2 = 0 or v_1 = \frac12v_2. Therefore the eigenvectors in E_4 have the form
\vvec=\twovec{v_1}{v_2} = \ctwovec{\frac12 v_2}{v_2} = v_2\ctwovec{1/2}{1}.
In other words, E_4 is a one-dimensional subspace of \real^2 with basis vector \ctwovec{1/2}{1} or basis vector \twovec12. In the same way, we find that a basis for the eigenspace E_2 is \twovec23.

We note that, for this matrix, it is possible to construct a basis of \real^2 consisting of eigenvectors, namely,
\bcal = \left\{\twovec12, \twovec23\right\}.

Consider the matrix A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix} whose characteristic equation is
\det(A-\lambda I) = \lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 4 = (\lambda-2)^2 =0.

There is a single eigenvalue \lambda= 2, and we find that
A - 2\lambda = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Therefore, the eigenspace E_2 = \nul(A-2I) is one-dimensional with a basis vector \twovec11.

If A=\begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} , then
\det(A - \lambda I) = (\lambda+1)^2 = 0,
which implies that there is a single eigenvalue \lambda=-1. We find that
A-(-1)I = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},
which says that every two-dimensional vector \vvec satisfies (A-(-1)I)\vvec = \zerovec. Therefore, every vector is an eigenvector and so E_{-1} = \real^2. This eigenspace is two-dimensional.

We can see this in another way. The matrix transformation defined by A rotates vectors by 180^\circ, which says that A\xvec = -\xvec for every vector \xvec. In other words, every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.

subsection.p: These last two examples illustrate two types of behavior when there is a single eigenvalue. In one case, we are able to construct a basis of \real^2 using eigenvectors; in the other, we are not. We will explore this behavior more in the next subsection.

assemblage.title: A check on our work
assemblage.p: When finding eigenvalues and their associated eigenvectors in this way, we first find eigenvalues \lambda by solving the characteristic equation. If \lambda is a solution to the characteristic equation, then A-\lambda I is not invertible and, consequently, A-\lambda I must contain a row without a pivot position.

This serves as a check on our work. If we row reduce A-\lambda I and find the identity matrix, then we have made an error either in solving the characteristic equation or in finding \nul(A-\lambda I).

subsection.title: The characteristic polynomial and the dimension of eigenspaces
subsection.p: Given a square n\times n matrix A, we saw in the previous section the value of being able to express any vector in \real^n as a linear combination of eigenvectors of A. For this reason, asks when we can construct a basis of \real^n consisting of eigenvectors. We will explore this question more fully now.

As we saw above, the eigenvalues of A are the solutions of the characteristic equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0. The examples we have considered demonstrate some different types of behavior. For instance, we have seen the characteristic equations
(4-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)(3-\lambda) = 0, which has real and distinct roots,
(2-\lambda)^2 = 0, which has repeated roots, and
\lambda^2 +1 = (i-\lambda)(-i-\lambda) = 0, which has complex roots.

If A is an n\times n matrix, then the characteristic polynomial is a degree n polynomial, and this means that it has n roots. Therefore, the characteristic equation can be written as
\det(A-\lambda I) = (\lambda_1 - \lambda)(\lambda_2-\lambda)\ldots(\lambda_n-\lambda) = 0
giving eigenvalues \lambda_1, \lambda_2,\ldots,\lambda_n. As we have seen, some of the eigenvalues may be complex. Moreover, some of the eigenvalues may appear in this list more than once. However, we can always write the characteristic equation in the form
(\lambda_1-\lambda)^{m_1} (\lambda_2-\lambda)^{m_2} \ldots (\lambda_p-\lambda)^{m_p} = 0.
The number of times that \lambda_j - \lambda appears as a factor in the characteristic polynomial, is called the multiplicity of the eigenvalue \lambda_j. multiplicity

statement.p: We have seen that the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] has the characteristic equation (2-\lambda)^2 = 0. This matrix has a single eigenvalue \lambda = 2, which has multiplicity 2.

If a matrix has the characteristic equation
(4-\lambda)^2(-5-\lambda)(1-\lambda)^7(3-\lambda)^2 = 0 , then that matrix has four eigenvalues: \lambda=4 having multiplicity 2; \lambda=-5 having multiplicity 1; \lambda=1 having multiplicity 7; and \lambda=3 having multiplicity 2. The degree of the characteristic polynomial is the sum of the multiplicities 2+1+7+2 = 12 so this matrix must be a 12\times12 matrix.

subsection.p: The multiplicities of the eigenvalues are important because they influence the dimension of the eigenspaces. We know that the dimension of an eigenspace must be at least one; the following proposition also tells us the dimension of an eigenspace can be no larger than the multiplicity of its associated eigenvalue.

statement.p:
If \lambda is a real eigenvalue of the matrix A with multiplicity m, then
1 \leq \dim~E_\lambda \leq m .

The diagonal matrix \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] has the characteristic equation (-1-\lambda)^2 = 0. There is a single eigenvalue \lambda = -1 having multiplicity m = 2, and we saw earlier that \dim E_{-1} = 2 \leq m = 2.

The matrix \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] has the characteristic equation (2-\lambda)^2 = 0. This tells us that there is a single eigenvalue \lambda = 2 having multiplicity m = 2. In contrast with the previous example, we have \dim~ E_2 = 1 \leq m = 2.

We saw earlier that the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 4 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] has the characteristic equation (4-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)(3-\lambda)=0. There are three eigenvalues \lambda=3,-2,1 each having multiplicity 1. By the proposition, we are guaranteed that the dimension of each eigenspace is 1; that is,
\dim E_3 = \dim E_{-2} = \dim E_1 = 1 . It turns out that this is enough to guarantee that there is a basis of \real^3 consisting of eigenvectors.

If a 12\times12 matrix has the characteristic equation
(4-\lambda)^2(-5-\lambda)(1-\lambda)^7(3-\lambda)^2 = 0 , we know there are four eigenvalues \lambda=4,-5,1,3. Without more information, all we can say about the dimensions of the eigenspaces is
\begin{aligned} 1 \leq \dim E_4 \amp {}\leq{} 2 \\ 1 \leq \dim E_{-5} \amp {}\leq{} 1 \\ 1 \leq \dim E_1 \amp {}\leq{} 7 \\ 1 \leq \dim E_3 \amp {}\leq{} 2\text{.} \\ \end{aligned}
We can guarantee that \dim E_{-5} = 1, but we cannot be more specific about the dimensions of the other eigenspaces.

subsection.p:
Fortunately, if we have an n\times n matrix, it frequently happens that the characteristic equation has the form
(\lambda_1-\lambda) (\lambda_2-\lambda) \ldots (\lambda_n-\lambda) = 0
where there are n distinct real eigenvalues, each of which has multiplicity 1. In this case, the dimension of each of the eigenspaces \dim E_{\lambda_j} = 1. With a little work, it can be seen that choosing a basis vector \vvec_j for each of the eigenspaces produces a basis for \real^n. We therefore have the following proposition.

statement.p: If A is an n\times n matrix having n distinct real eigenvalues, then there is a basis of \real^n consisting of eigenvectors of A.

subsection.p: This proposition provides one answer to our . The next activity explores this question further.

The dimension of the matrix is 14\times14 since the degree of the characteristic polynomial is 14. We cannot guarantee that we can form a basis for \real^{14} consisting of eigenvectors, however.

We have eigenvalues \lambda=-2 with multiplicity 2 and \lambda=-1 with multiplicity 1.
The eigenspace E_{-2} is two-dimensional with basis \left\{\threevec{-2}{0}{1},\threevec010\right\}. The eigenspace E_{-1} is one-dimensional with basis vector \threevec{-1}20.

We have eigenvalues \lambda=-2 with multiplicity 2 and \lambda=-1 with multiplicity 1.

We can form a basis for \real^3 consisting of eigenvectors of A.

subsection.title: Using Sage to find eigenvalues and eigenvectors
subsection.p: We can use Sage to find the characteristic polynomial, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of a matrix. As we will see, however, some care is required when dealing with matrices whose entries include decimals.

statement.p:
We will use Sage to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix. Let's begin with the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -3 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] .
We can find the characteristic polynomial of A by writing A.charpoly('lambda'). Notice that we have to give Sage a variable in which to write the polynomial; here, we use lambda though x works just as well.
A = matrix(2,2,[-3,1,0,-3]) A.charpoly('lambda')
The factored form of the characteristic polynomial may be more useful since it will tell us the eigenvalues and their multiplicities. The factored characteristic polynomial is found with A.fcp('lambda').
A = matrix(2,2,[-3,1,0,-3]) A.fcp('lambda')
If we only want the eigenvalues, we can use A.eigenvalues().
A = matrix(2,2,[-3,1,0,-3]) A.eigenvalues()
Notice that the multiplicity of an eigenvalue is the number of times it is repeated in the list of eigenvalues.
Finally, we can find eigenvectors by A.eigenvectors_right(). (We are looking for right eigenvalues since the vector \vvec appears to the right of A in the definition A\vvec=\lambda \vvec.)
A = matrix(2,2,[-3,1,0,-3]) A.eigenvectors_right()
At first glance, the result of this command can be a little confusing to interpret. What we see is a list with one entry for each eigenvalue. For each eigenvalue, there is a triple consisting of (i) the eigenvalue \lambda, (ii) a basis for E_\lambda, and (iii) the multiplicity of \lambda.
When working with decimal entries, which are called floating point numbers in computer science, we must remember that computers perform only approximate arithmetic. This is a problem when we wish to find the eigenvectors of such a matrix. To illustrate, consider the matrix A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.4 \amp 0.3 \\ 0.6 \amp 0.7 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Without using Sage, find the eigenvalues of this matrix.
What do you find for the reduced row echelon form of A-I?
Let's now use Sage to determine the reduced row echelon form of A-I:
A = matrix(2,2,[0.4,0.3,0.6,0.7]) (A-identity_matrix(2)).rref()
What result does Sage report for the reduced row echelon form? Why is this result not correct?
Because the arithmetic Sage performs with floating point entries is only approximate, we are not able to find the eigenspace E_1. In this next chapter, we will learn how to address this issue. In the meantime, we can get around this problem by writing the entries in the matrix as rational numbers:
A = matrix(2,2,[4/10,3/10,6/10,7/10]) A.eigenvectors_right()

li.p: The fcp command will return the factored characteristic polynomial lambda^2 - 2*lambda - 3.
The eigenvalues command returns a list of eigenvalues [-3, -3].
The eigenvectors_right command returns [(-3, [(1, 0)], 2)].

If we begin with the matrix A, we find
The eigenvalues are \lambda=1 and \lambda=0.1.
The reduced row echelon form is \mattwo{-2}{1}{0}{0}, which shows that A-I is not invertible, as expected.
Sage returns \mattwo{1}{0}{0}{1}, which is not correct because A-I cannot be invertible if \lambda=1 is an eigenvalue of A.
Here we find the correct eigenvalues, \lambda=1 with basis vector \twovec{1}{2} for E_1 and \lambda=0.1 with basis vector \twovec{1}{-1} for E_{0.1}.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
In this section, we developed a technique for finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of an n\times n matrix A.
The expression \det(A-\lambda I) is a degree n polynomial, known as the characteristic polynomial of A. The eigenvalues of A are the roots of the characteristic polynomial found by solving the characteristic equation \det(A-\lambda I) = 0.
The set of eigenvectors associated to the eigenvalue \lambda forms a subspace of \real^n, the eigenspace E_\lambda = \nul(A-\lambda I).
If the factor (\lambda_j - \lambda) appears m_j times in the characteristic polynomial, we say that the eigenvalue \lambda_j has multiplicity m_j and note that
1 \leq \dim E_{\lambda_j} \leq m_j .
If each of the eigenvalues is real and has multiplicity 1, then we can form a basis of \real^n consisting of eigenvectors of A.
We can use Sage to find the eigenvalues and eigenvalues of matrices. However, we need to be careful working with floating point numbers since floating point arithmetic is only an approximation.

statement.p: Determine whether each of the statements about the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of a square matrix A is Always True, Never True, or Sometimes True.

match.premise: If \det(A+4I)=0, then \lambda=-4 is an eigenvalue of A.
If \lambda=3 is an eigenvalue of A, then E_3=\nul(A-3I).
If \lambda = 0 is an eigenvalue of A, then \det(A) = 0.
If \nul(A-5I)=\{0\}, then \lambda=5 is not an eigenvalue of A.
If \lambda is an eigenvalue of a matrix A, then A-\lambda I is row equivalent to I.
If the columns of A+I are linearly independent, then \lambda=-1 is an eigenvalue of A.
The eigenvalues of a matrix are its diagonal entries.
If (\lambda-3)^2 is a factor of the characteristic polynomial of A, then \dim E_3 = 2.
